title: Riot knows what you search on google...
body:
Just try these things out and see what happens:

1. Open any Browser.
2. Type in 'cheat engine' and then search for it. (cheat'ing' engine won't work)
3. Don't click on any link or download anything.
4. Leave the tab open.
5. Open a game in Practice tool (or anywhere really, although I do not recommend it). :)
6. Wait till second 3 of the game.
7. If you play on fullscreen... well, something's gonna hinder you closing the game, not that you'd want that, or maybe you do? :) Alt+F4 won't work :b

replies.body: The League Client, as can any other program, has access to certain information about other programs running on your computer. This is used by most competent developers to enable compatibility concerns to resolve, prevent crashes, ensure memory is not corrupted or edited by other programs, and yes, to prevent cheating.
That makes sense, just wanted people to know, cause, y'know, it's kinda funny.

I'll go out on a limb here, and state that if this client prevents other programs or even features of other programs or even limit the client itself from running properly because certain search words, HEX values or other blacklisted / presumed cheats (that are not in any way interacting with the client) are found in these RAM scans, then that's not legal.

"access to certain information about other programs running on your computer" (i.e. read access) and automatically taking active, preventive measures without the user's knowledge or consent are 2 very different things.

I have read the EULA and ToS on this, but there it was just very generally phrased. I just applied the classic "we can do whatever we want, while you got no rights" view on it (considering we are just _renting_ content here after all). So I'd really like some specifics here.

Or to be very specific myself: 
I got on occasion cheats, trainers, RAM injectors, screen overlays and HEX modifiers for other games running . Sometimes while the LoL client is running as well; forgetting about it in the profile screen, and not interacting with it.

Should I be worried? I don't feel worried, nor do I feel I should be worried.

Not like what I did here anyway, running LoL at 5760 x 1200 resolution through a simple .cfg modification:
https://1drv.ms/u/s!AuFMZD__7mN2gTCl5GTrI1e6ijPF

Riot is allowed to do whatever they want to their client. If they want to force their client to close or not run when certain other programs are running, that's their right.

League does not, to my knowledge, interact with any other programs - it simply monitors the processes and memory and any action taken is by the league client on the league client.

On its own, that fine. But then I do expect some proper error messages should the RAM scan detect something it doesn't like.

If the scans make the client fail to run because I got Cheat Engine (or other software) open, that's also fine - as long as the client informs me it won't run while certain programs are running. Obviously not by name - as that would be a long, ever-changing list - but by, if even probable, feature.

But here I suspect it's easier to just ban the person "for unauthorized 3rd party programs" (whether those programs interacts with the LoL client or not) than actually inform them of anything, as - as you say - it's their client, and as I say, we got no rights.

But I'm not concerned about any actual cheat accusations for this game. Yes, I've modded everything that could be modded here once upon a time, but Tencent have effectively killed off any such entertainment now.

This is untrue.  There are all sorts of laws (depending on the region/country) that dictate what you can and cannot do.  TOS/EULA does not mean sht.

Show me **one** law, from anywhere in the world (any free country, i.e. not China, Russia, North Korea, etc) that limits the authority of a program to **alter itself**.

There is no law/court case that limits the ability of a program to crash or close itself if it does not want to run anymore.

You stated: "Riot is allowed to do whatever they want to their client."

I'm not saying it can't close itself, rather that it can't scan your system at will, or do what it wants with the information without your consent.

Also when you purchase software, there is a contractual obligation by the company, now RIOT can't close league if/when it chooses, but not all software can.  If you paid for something and it doesn't work, you can request a refund or compensation.

Really what it can or cannot do depends on the location (so if you want specifics you'll have to be specific as well).

You don't purchase the software. It is provided free of charge.

They... really don't have any contractual obligation. Furthermore, you provide no basis for any law prohibiting programs from scanning other processes. In fact, this is probably not something that will be legislated - as it is the OS developer's choice, has no implications for privacy, etc, and is a competition factor. Data *protection* and *privacy* regulations only cover **collection** or **storing** of data. The League client is doing neither, it simply closes out if it detects other processes that are on its "list" or accessing its memory.

> [{quoted}](name=Aladoron,realm=EUW,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=5grHajmf,comment-id=0000000200000002000100000000000000000001,timestamp=2019-01-01T08:27:01.097+0000)
>
> And how do you know this? Also how can Rito examine the data if it doesn't "get the data"? Do you know this check is run client side?

If you want to know if the check is happening client side or server side, use Wireshark or some other packet sniffer. Start League with no programs open, don't move for 15 seconds, then quit the match. Then start up Chrome with a bunch of tabs open, start League, don't move for 15 seconds, then quit the match. The traffic should be nearly identical if it's done client side, but there should be a lot more packets sent if it's remote.

Honestly, I could see Riot going either way with this one. It's easy to send the client a few phrases to search for and die on, but if you suspect someone is cheating then you'd want to know what their program is called, which means you'd want it returned to the server.

Not a bad idea, but Rito could easily send the list of open window titles in one single packet, and get back a simple bool to crash or not. So checking for simply the number of packets is not surely a good idea. Checking the whole size of the communication might work better, but i'm still not sure.

One could disassemble the exe, but that's just too much pain in the ass for a beginner like me.

And the main point of the question was how HE knows it. Since I clearly doubt he did any backcheck on his statement, he just spreads any kind of BS he thinks of in the defense of Rito. Or at least this is how his other comments looked like for me.
